subject: Add D-Bus interface for a logical volume
commitMessage:
Add D-Bus interface for a logical volume

Add an initial D-Bus interface for a logical volume, which will be used
for eStoraged. It includes the following methods: FormatLuks, Lock,
Unlock, and ChangePassword.

The design doc for eStoraged can be found here:
https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/designs/estoraged.md

Signed-off-by: John Wedig <johnwedig@google.com>
Signed-off-by: John Edward Broadbent <jebr@google.com>
Change-Id: I7975056e52901a82b36933b51fb3eea112818385

Patch Set 11:

I've updated this review to address some feedback from Ed. Ed suggested that eStoraged expose a couple different D-Bus interfaces:
- /xyz/openbmc_project/Inventory/Item/Drive
- /xyz/openbmc_project/Inventory/Item/Volume

The former interface will be used for device-level operations, e.g. device locking, and the latter interface will be used for the logical volume, e.g. LUKS-related operations.

I updated this code review to introduce the volume interface. The content of this code review is still mostly the same, just under a different D-Bus path.

nit: what type of file system does it create? I assume ext4
Yes, it's ext4. I clarified that here.
nit: Capitalization

I wasn't sure about this. I changed it be capitalized.

Either way, the parameters in the generated code start with lower-case.
nit: Capitalization
Done
nit: Capitalization
Done
nit: Capitalization

nit: Capitalization
Done
nit: Capitalization
Done

Nit: I am not sure you want the default to be True.
It is fine with me.
Yeah, maybe it should be false by default. Ultimately, when eStoraged first starts up, I think it should check whether the device is already LUKS encrypted and then set this accordingly.
super nit: I would rather Success mean the device is locked, rather then no errors.
I tried to clarify this, but I intend for this enum to be used for any of the above methods. For example, success could also mean that we successfully unlocked it.

see
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/48664/1
Yes, I meant for this to only be a placeholder for now. You'll fill in the enum values in your subsequent commit.
Might be good to link the design doc you've submitted here for easier reference.
Good call. I added the link here.
I think we use small case false for boolean https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/search?q=%22default%3A+false%22
Good catch. Done.
question: what alternatives were we thinking for this enum (does it need to be an enum?) AllFFs?
It seems like this is resolved now with the latest patch.
I assume this attempts to unmount too?
Yes, I updated the description to say that.
nit: missing newline in between properties.
Done
You should get back an error in coordination with the method, why would you want this if you can't know the exact order of transactions before you?

Since some of the D-Bus methods might take a while, namely format and erase, I was thinking they might need to be asynchronous, to avoid exceeding the D-Bus timeout. So, after calling the Format method, for example, the caller would need to query the status, to see whether it finished or hit an error, or whether it's still running.

Do you think it makes sense to do it this way? Making the D-Bus methods synchronous would certainly be simpler, as long as D-Bus timeouts aren't an issue.

The concern is good, but we should allow that level of asynchronicity to happen at the DBus call level. As long as the daemon is responding to pings, the requests shouldn't time out and you can increase per-call timeouts as desired for these operations.
Alright, it seems like this status enum shouldn't be necessary. I removed it.
I wonder if these should be in the design doc as well?

I didn't think these values needed to be in the design doc, since some of this is specific to Google. One thing that came up during the design doc review is that different organizations have their own ideas of what a secure erase actually entails. So, we wanted to allow other people to add their own erase operations, if they want. And if someone does choose to add another erase type, a new entry would be added to this enum.

If people think the design doc needs more documentation regarding the erase, let me know.
I wonder if someone has a better suggestion for defining these values in a per-oem way with a provided simple secure erase procedure in a single step.

That is good question, and I understand how that could be useful for others.

Our disk erase service manages the erase state. So this service expects to be able to do any of the 8 steps above, and get a result.
Why ext4?  What if I want to use something else someday?  Need a new API?  Should this simply be "whatever filesystem the managing daemon decides to use"?

I added a parameter for filesystem type. We might want that.

But on a related note, there are a number of other things that we could expose as parameters. For example, the LUKS type, the cipher mode, mount point, etc. Would it make sense to have a general options parameter, so that we have the ability to support specific things like that without changing the API?
Is this restricted to LUKS based implementations?  Should this be documented in the API?
I changed the description at the top to specify LUKS.

Before I ask it, I'll preface I don't have a good answer for this question and I don't see anything necessarily see anything wrong with this breakdown in error classification.


As a user of your API, what am I expected to do with these?  Generally, we've been trying to get rid of InternalError because there is no method that I, as a user of your API, can determine how to get your code into a state where the call will be successful.  I don't see either of these errors as much different.  If I get "EncryptionError" from your API, how do I get the system into a state where it won't give "EncryptionError" anymore?

Hmm, I think I see what you mean. These errors alone don't really tell you much. What you would have to do is probably check the logs to hopefully get more information about what went wrong.

There might be certain things I could create more specific errors for. For example, if we fail to unlock the device, there's a good chance the password is wrong. Or if we can't unmount the filesystem, something is probably still using it. Maybe some more specific error types would help a little bit. But there would be other cases where you have to look at logs.
Why do I need a password to erase the contents?

Initially, I was thinking we might want the password for a couple reasons:
  - We might need the password to unlock the device at the firmware level.
  - We could use the password to verify that the erase actually worked, and that we can no longer unlock it.

But neither of these things really make the password necessary. In the case of an eMMC, you can force erase the device without a password, even if it's locked (or the caller could call unlock first, I suppose). And if someone really wants to make sure they can't unlock the LUKS device anymore, they can try calling the unlock method afterwards.

I removed this password parameter.
I'm similarly surprised you need a password to 'lock' a device.  Is this a hardware-level password?  I thought locking a device was simply forgetting the encryption handles?

To lock the LUKS device itself, you don't need a password. But locking at the device level does need a password, at least in the case of an eMMC. I updated the description, to say why this password parameter is here.
Did we ever settle on terminology for this (Locked)?
I don't remember discussing this. Is there something you think should be clarified?

This is me, from drives (here in phosphor-dbus-interfaces)
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/47657

And I hope to get back to this today.

These are nice for potential debug, but as an API, what are your clients expected to do with these?  Is there something they can do to recover?  Was this due to them passing bad parameters, your daemon being in a bad state, the kernel being messed up?  How are these any better than Common.InternalFailure (which we don't like to have)?
I removed these custom errors, since they probably don't gain us much. I'll plan on using the errors in Common.errors.
Should this be an enumeration?  How does someone calling this interface know what are valid strings?
I added an enumeration for this, currently with 4 filesystem types. We can add more in the future, if we want.
It seems like Common.UnsuportedRequest would be an error depending on the FilesystemType parameter value?
I added Common.UnsupportedRequest. I changed the errors throughout this file to reference those in Common.errors.yaml.
